perturbation.original_text: Within 7 Business Days after the end of each calendar quarter, the Billing Party shall provide the other party with an itemized statement, subject to adjustment within 30 days of receipt of such statement, setting forth the Net Revenue achieved over the preceding calendar quarter, and shall include such other information as may be mutually agreed upon by the parties (the "Revenue Report").
perturbation.changed_text: Within 60 Business Days after the end of each calendar quarter, the Billing Party shall provide the other party with an itemized statement, subject to adjustment within 5 days of receipt of such statement, setting forth the Net Revenue achieved over the preceding calendar quarter, and shall include such other information as may be mutually agreed upon by the parties (the "Revenue Report").
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires the Billing Party to provide an itemized statement within 7 business days. Changing this to 60 business days introduces a delay that may conflict with standard accounting practices and potentially violate regulations requiring timely financial reporting. Also, reducing the adjustment period from 30 days to 5 days is unreasonable and contradicts standard business practice of a longer adjustment period, creating an imbalance and potential legal challenges.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violations of generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP) and regulations concerning timely financial reporting. Also breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing.

perturbation.original_text:
The Billing Party may deduct and withhold from any payments due to the other party under this Agreement any and all taxes and other amounts as required under the laws of any jurisdiction that has the authority to tax the Billing Party, the other party or the transactions contemplated by this Agreement. However, should the Billing Party consider withholding payment or paying any such amount from payments due under this Agreement, the Billing Party shall send in advance to the other party a certificate setting forth the regulatory and/or legal framework for such a payment, including the provisions of the international tax treaty allowing such payment. The other party will have 30 days from the reception of such information to accept or refuse such payment/withholding:

    (i)  If the other party accepts or does not answer within this time frame,           the Billing Party will be entitled to make such payment/withholding           and shall provide the other party with a certificate stating the           amounts withheld and the jurisdictions to which such amounts were           remitted.
perturbation.changed_text:
The Billing Party may deduct and withhold from any payments due to the other party under this Agreement any and all taxes and other amounts as required under the laws of any jurisdiction that has the authority to tax the Billing Party, the other party or the transactions contemplated by this Agreement. However, should the Billing Party consider withholding payment or paying any such amount from payments due under this Agreement, the Billing Party is not required to send in advance to the other party a certificate setting forth the regulatory and/or legal framework for such a payment, including the provisions of the international tax treaty allowing such payment. The other party will have 5 days from the reception of such information to accept or refuse such payment/withholding:

    (i)  If the other party accepts or does not answer within this time frame,           the Billing Party will be entitled to make such payment/withholding           and is not obligated to provide the other party with a certificate stating the amounts withheld and the jurisdictions to which such amounts were remitted.
perturbation.explanation: The original text requires the Billing Party to send the other party a certificate outlining the basis for tax withholding and gives the other party 30 days to respond. The modified version removes the requirement for the certificate entirely and shortens the response time to 5 days. This is contradictory because, under US tax laws and international tax treaties, the withholding party often has a legal obligation to provide documentation of withholding. Furthermore, shortening the time frame to 5 days is unreasonable because this is too short for the other party to determine if the tax amounts are correct.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of IRS regulations and international tax treaty obligations requiring documentation of tax withholding.

perturbation.original_text: Either party may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the other party is in default or breach of any material provision of this Agreement, and such default or breach continues unremedied for a period of sixty days after written notice thereof.
perturbation.changed_text: Either party may terminate this Agreement at any time in the event that the other party is in default or breach of any material provision of this Agreement, and such default or breach continues unremedied for a period of ten days after written notice thereof.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period from 60 days to 10 days is contradictory because it's an unreasonably short amount of time to fix material provisions.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of covenant of good faith and fair dealing.
